tit.j: 日本神話における食物起源神話
tit.e: Myth of Food Origin in Japanese Mythology
Myth of Food Origin in Japanese Mythology
Myth of Food Origin in Japanese Mythology

sen.j: この記事では、日本神話における食物起源神話について記述する。
sen.e: This article describes myth of food origin in Japanese Mythology.
This article describes myth of food origin in Japanese Mythology.
This article describes myth of food origin in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 日本神話における食物起源の記述には、東南アジアでよく見られるハイヌウェレ神話の特徴が見られる。
sen.e: Descriptions of food origin in Japanese Mythology show the characteristics of the myth of Hainuwele that is commonly found in Southeast Asia.
Descriptions of food origin in Japanese Mythology show the characteristics of the myth of Hainuwele that is commonly found in Southeast Asia.
Descriptions of food origin in Japanese Mythology show the characteristics of the myth of Hainuwele that is commonly found in Southeast Asia.

sen.j: 即ち、排泄物から食物などを生み出す神を殺すことで食物の種が生まれたとするものである。
sen.e: This myth indicates that the seeds of food were produced by killing a god that produces food from excretions.
This myth indicates that the seeds of food were produced by killing a god that produces food from excretions.
This myth indicates that the seeds of food were produced by killing a god that produces food from excretions.

sen.j: また、天から食物の種を携えた神が天降って来たとする記述も見られる。
sen.e: There are also descriptions that a god with seeds of food came down from the heaven.
There are also descriptions that a god with seeds of food came down from the heaven.
There are also descriptions that a god with seeds of food came down from the heaven.

sen.j: これはギリシャのデメテル神話に類似している。
sen.e: This myth resembles to the myth of Demeter in Greece.
This myth resembles to the myth of Demeter in Greece.
This myth resembles to the myth of Demeter in Greece.

sen.j: ハイヌウェレ神話型
sen.e: Hainuwele-type myth
Hainuwele-type myth
Hainuwele-type myth

sen.j: オオゲツヒメとスサノオ
sen.e: Ogetsuhime and Susanoo
Ogetsuhime and Susanoo
Ogetsuhime and Susanoo

sen.j: 古事記においては、岩戸隠れの後に高天原を追放されたスサノオ（速須佐之男命）が、食物神であるオオゲツヒメ（大気都比売神）に食物を求めた話として出てくる。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), this type of myth is found in a tale that Susanoo (Takehaya Susano no Mikoto) who was expelled from the Plain of High Heaven after Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), asked for food from Ogetsuhime (Ogetsuhime no kami), a deity of grains.

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), this type of myth is found in a tale that Susanoo (Takehaya Susano no Mikoto) who was expelled from the Plain of High Heaven after Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), asked for food from Ogetsuhime (Ogetsuhime no kami), a deity of grains.

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), this type of myth is found in a tale that Susanoo (Takehaya Susano no Mikoto) who was expelled from the Plain of High Heaven after Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave), asked for food from Ogetsuhime (Ogetsuhime no kami), a deity of grains.

sen.j: オオゲツヒメは、鼻や口、尻から様々な食材を取り出して調理してスサノオに差しあげた。
sen.e: Ogetsuhime produced various foodstuffs from her mouth, nose, and rectum, preparing them and offering them to Susanoo.
Ogetsuhime produced various foodstuffs from her mouth, nose, and rectum, preparing them and offering them to Susanoo.
Ogetsuhime produced various foodstuffs from her mouth, nose, and rectum, preparing them and offering them to Susanoo.

sen.j: しかし、スサノオがその様子を覗き見、食物を汚して差し出したと思って、オオゲツヒメを殺してしまった。
sen.e: Incensed that she had presented foods taken out of her body in a filthy way, Susanoo killed Ogetsuhime.
But Susannoo had a peep at that situation and incensed that she had presented foods taken out of her body in a filthy way, so Susanoo killed Ogetsuhime.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「その様子を覗き見、」の部分を足しました。
sen.e: But Susannoo had a peep at that situation and incensed that she had presented foods taken out of her body in a filthy way, so Susanoo killed Ogetsuhime.

sen.j: オオゲツヒメの屍体から様々な食物の種などが生まれた。
sen.e: Various grains and seeds then appeared from her corpse.
Various grains and seeds then appeared from her corpse.
Various grains and seeds then appeared from her corpse.

sen.j: 頭に蚕、目に稲、耳に粟、鼻に小豆、陰部に麦、尻に大豆が生まれた。
sen.e: Products include silkworms from her head, rice from her eyes, millet from her ears, red beans from her nose, barley from her genitals, and soybeans from her rectum.
Products include silkworms from her head, rice from her eyes, millet from her ears, red beans from her nose, barley from her genitals, and soybeans from her rectum.
Products include silkworms from her head, rice from her eyes, millet from her ears, red beans from her nose, barley from her genitals, and soybeans from her rectum.

sen.j: カミムスビ（神産巣日御祖命）はこれらを取って五穀の種とした。
sen.e: Kamimusubi (Kamimusuhimioya no mikoto) used the resulting grains as seeds for planting.
Kamimusubi (Kamimusuhimioya no mikoto) used the resulting grains as seeds for planting.
Kamimusubi (Kamimusuhimioya no mikoto) used the resulting grains as seeds for planting.

sen.j: ウケモチとツクヨミ
sen.e: Ukemochi and Tsukuyomi
Ukemochi and Tsukuyomi
Ukemochi and Tsukuyomi

sen.j: 日本書紀においては、同様の説話が神産みの第十一の一書にツクヨミ（月夜見尊）とウケモチ（保食神）の話として出てくる。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), a similar myth called the myth of Ukemochi no kami and Tsukuyomi is found in an alternate writing in the 11th section of Kamiumi (bearing gods between Izanagi and Izanami) section.

In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), a similar myth called the myth of Ukemochi no kami and Tsukuyomi is found in an alternate writing in the 11th section of Kamiumi (bearing gods between Izanagi and Izanami) section.

In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), a similar myth called the myth of Ukemochi no kami and Tsukuyomi is found in an alternate writing in the 11th section of Kamiumi (bearing gods between Izanagi and Izanami) section.

sen.j: アマテラスはツクヨミに、葦原中国にいるウケモチという神を見てくるよう命じた。
sen.e: Amaterasu ordered Tsukuyomi to watch over a deity called Ukemochi in Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world).
Amaterasu ordered Tsukuyomi to watch over a deity called Ukemochi in Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world).
Amaterasu ordered Tsukuyomi to watch over a deity called Ukemochi in Ashihara no nakatsukuni (Literally, "Central Land of Reed Plains", which refers to the human world).

sen.j: ツクヨミがウケモチの所へ行くと、ウケモチは、口から米飯、魚、毛皮の動物を出し、それらでツクヨミをもてなした。
sen.e: Tsukuyomi visited Ukemochi who then treated Tsukuyomi by serving rice, fishes, and fur animals that were produced from her mouth.
Tsukuyomi visited Ukemochi who then treated Tsukuyomi by serving rice, fishes, and fur animals that were produced from her mouth.
Tsukuyomi visited Ukemochi who then treated Tsukuyomi by serving rice, fishes, and fur animals that were produced from her mouth.

sen.j: ツクヨミは汚らわしいと怒り、ウケモチを斬ってしまった。
sen.e: Incensed that the foods were filthy, Tsukuyomi slew Ukemochi.
Incensed that the foods were filthy, Tsukuyomi slew Ukemochi.
Incensed that the foods were filthy, Tsukuyomi slew Ukemochi.

sen.j: それを聞いたアマテラスは怒り、もうツクヨミとは会いたくないと言った。
sen.e: On hearing the news, Amaterasu was angered and said that she didn't want to see him anymore.
On hearing the news, Amaterasu was angered and said that she didn't want to see him anymore.
On hearing the news, Amaterasu was angered and said that she didn't want to see him anymore.

sen.j: それで太陽と月は昼と夜とに別れて出るようになったのである。
sen.e: That is why the sun and the moon appear separately in day and night.
That is why the sun and the moon appear separately during the day and at night.
sen.cmt: in day and nightの部分を修正しました。
sen.e: That is why the sun and the moon appear separately during the day and at night.

sen.j: アマテラスがウケモチの所にアメノクマヒト（天熊人）を遣すと、ウケモチは死んでいた。
sen.e: Amaterasu sent Amenokumahito to Ukemochi who had already been dead.
Amaterasu sent Amenokumahito to Ukemochi, who had already been dead.
Amaterasu sent Amenokumahito to Ukemochi, who had already been dead.

sen.j: ウケモチの屍体の頭から牛馬、額から粟、眉から蚕、目から稗、腹から稲、陰部から麦・大豆・小豆が生まれた。
sen.e: Various grains appeared from Ukemochi's corpse, including cows and horses from her head, millet from her forehead, silkworms from her eyebrows, Japanese millet from her eyes, rice from her abdomen, and barley, red beans and soybeans from her genitals.

Various grains appeared from Ukemochi's corpse, including cows and horses from her head, millet from her forehead, silkworms from her eyebrows, Japanese millet from her eyes, rice from her abdomen, and barley, red beans and soybeans from her genitals.

Various grains appeared from Ukemochi's corpse, including cows and horses from her head, millet from her forehead, silkworms from her eyebrows, Japanese millet from her eyes, rice from her abdomen, and barley, red beans and soybeans from her genitals.

sen.j: アメノクマヒトがこれらを全て持ち帰ると、アマテラスは喜び、民が生きてゆくために必要な食物だとしてこれらを田畑の種とした。
sen.e: Amenokumahito took them all to Amaterasu who was pleased and used the resulting grains as seeds for planting in the fields because these were indispensable foods for people.
Amenokumahito took them all to Amaterasu, who was pleased and used the resulting grains as seeds for planting in the fields because these were indispensable foods for people.
Amenokumahito took them all to Amaterasu, who was pleased and used the grains as seeds for planting in the fields because these were indispensable foods for people.

sen.j: ワクムスビ
sen.e: Wakumusubi
Wakumusubi
Wakumusubi

sen.j: また、日本書紀における神産みの第二の一書には、火の神カグツチと、イザナミが亡くなる直前に生んだ土の神ハニヤマヒメの間に生まれたワクムスビ（稚産霊）の頭の上に蚕と桑が生じ、臍（ほぞ）の中に五穀が生まれたという説話がある。
sen.e: In an alternate writing in the second section of the Kamiumi in Nihonshoki, there is a tale that the deity of fire Kagutsuchi and the deity of earth Haniyamahime, to whom Izanami gave birth immediately before she died, had a child called Wakumusubi who produced silkworm and mulberry from her head and five grains inside her navel.

In an alternate writing in the second section of the Kamiumi in Nihonshoki, there is a tale that Wakumusubi who was born of the deity of fire Kagutsuchi and the deity of earth Haniyamahime whom Izanami gave birth immediately before she died, produced silkworm and mulberry from her head and five grains inside her navel.
sen.cmt: ワクムスビを主語にして、全体を少し修正しました。
sen.e: In an alternate writing in the second section of the Kamiumi in Nihonshoki, there is a tale that Wakumusubi who was born of the deity of fire Kagutsuchi and the deity of earth Haniyamahime whom Izanami gave birth immediately before she died, produced silkworm and mulberry from her head and five grains inside her navel.

sen.j: ワクムスビが死んだ（殺された）かどうかの記述はないが、ハイヌウェレ神話型に分類されるものである。
sen.e: There is no description whether Wakumusubi died (was killed) or not, but this tale falls into the category of Hainuwele myth.
There is no description whether Wakumusubi died (was killed) or not, but this tale falls into the category of Hainuwele myth.
There is no description whether Wakumusubi died (was killed) or not, but this tale falls into the category of Hainuwele myth.

sen.j: デメテル神話型
sen.e: Demeter-type myth
Demeter-type myth
Demeter-type myth

sen.j: ニニギ
sen.e: Ninigi
Ninigi

sen.j: 日本書紀における天孫降臨の第二の一書には、アマテラスが、高天原にある稲穂をアメノオシホミミに授け、オシホミミは天降る際に生まれたニニギにそれを授けて天に帰ったとの記述がある。
sen.e: In an alternate writing in the second section of the Tenson Korin (descent of the heavenly grandchild) in Nihonshoki, Amaterasu gave a rice ear in the plain of high heaven to Ame no Oshihomimi, and he gave it to Ninigi who was born while Oshihomimi was descending, and went back to the heaven.

In an alternate writing in the second section of the Tenson Korin (descent of the heavenly grandchild) in Nihonshoki, Amaterasu gave a rice ear in the plain of high heaven to Ame no Oshihomimi, and he gave it to Ninigi who was born while Oshihomimi was falling from heaven, and went back to the heaven.
sen.cmt: Oshihomimi was descendingの部分を少し修正しました。
sen.e: In an alternate writing in the second section of the Tenson Korin (descent of the heavenly grandchild) in Nihonshoki, Amaterasu gave a rice ear in the plain of high heaven to Ame no Oshihomimi, and he gave it to Ninigi who was born while Oshihomimi was falling from heaven, and went back to the heaven.

sen.j: また、日向国風土記逸文には、天降ったニニギが天から持って来た籾を地上に撒き散らしたとある。
sen.e: Hyuga-no-kuni Fudoki Itsubun (unknown description of regional climate, culture, etc. of Hyuga Province) describes that Ninigi descended from the heaven with rice in the husk and threw them about on the ground.

Hyuga-no-kuni Fudoki Itsubun (unknown description of regional climate, culture, etc. of Hyuga Province) describes that Ninigi fallen from the heaven with rice in the husk threw them about on the ground.

Hyuga-no-kuni Fudoki Itsubun (unknown description of regional climate, culture, etc. of Hyuga Province) describes that Ninigi fallen from the heaven with rice in the husk threw them about on the ground.

sen.j: 伊雑宮における神話では、稲はアマテラスが、高天原の斎の神田にある稲穂を持ち込んだとされる。
sen.e: According to a myth in Izawanomiya, rice in Japan was brought by Amaterasu from divine rice field in the itsuki in the plain of high heaven.
According to a myth in Izawanomiya, rice in Japan was brought by Amaterasu from divine rice field in the itsuki in the plain of high heaven.
According to a myth in Izawanomiya, rice in Japan was brought by Amaterasu from divine rice field in the itsuki in the plain of high heaven.

sen.j: イソタケル
sen.e: Isotakeru
Isotakeru
Isotakeru

sen.j: 日本書紀におけるヤマタノオロチ退治の第四の一書では、高天原を追放されたスサノオは新羅に降りたが、「ここにはいたくない」と言って出雲へ向かう。
sen.e: According to an alternate writing in the fourth section that depicts extermination of Yamata no Orochi (eight forked great serpent) in Nihonshoki, Susanoo who was banished from the Plain of High Heaven descended to the Korean Kingdom of Silla, but he said he didn't want to be there and moved to Izumo.

According to an alternate writing in the fourth section that depicts extermination of Yamata no Orochi (eight forked great serpent) in Nihonshoki, Susanoo who was banished from the Plain of High Heaven descended to the Korean Kingdom of Silla, but he said he didn't want to be there and moved to Izumo.

According to an alternate writing in the fourth section that depicts extermination of Yamata no Orochi (eight forked great serpent) in Nihonshoki, Susanoo who was banished from the Plain of High Heaven descended to the Korean Kingdom of Silla, but he said he didn't want to be there and moved to Izumo.

sen.j: この時、スサノオの子のイソタケル（五十猛神）は高天原から持って来た木々の種を新羅には植えず大八洲国（日本）に撒いたので、大八洲国は青々とした地になったとしている。
sen.e: An offspring of Susanoo, Isotakeru descended with his father bearing tree seeds, but he did not plant them to the Korean kingdom of Silla and instead he sowed the seeds throughout Oyashima-guni (Japan, meaning Eight Great Islands) that became the land of forests.

A child of Susanoo, Isotakeru brought some tree seeds, but he did not plant them to the Korean kingdom of Silla and instead he sowed the seeds throughout Oyashima-guni (Japan, meaning Eight Great Islands), which became the land of forests.
sen.cmt: offspring→child、with his father～→ brought、 that→, which に修正しました。
sen.e: A child of Susanoo, Isotakeru brought some tree seeds, but he did not plant them to the Korean kingdom of Silla and instead he sowed the seeds throughout Oyashima-guni (Japan, meaning Eight Great Islands), which became the land of forests.

sen.j: 上記の神話とは異なるが、おとめ座（デメテル）の持っている麦穂（スピカ）はギリシャでは麦星と呼ばれている。
sen.e: Although it is not the same as the myth described above, in Greece, the ear of wheat (Spica) in the hand of the Virgin (Demeter) is called the star of wheat.
Although it is not the same as the myth described above, in Greece, the ear of wheat (Spica) in the hand of the Virgin (Demeter) is called the star of wheat.
Although it is not the same as the myth described above, in Greece, the ear of wheat (Spica) in the hand of the Virgin (Demeter) is called the star of wheat.

sen.j: 日本では牛飼い座のアルクトゥルスが麦星と呼ばれている。
sen.e: In Japan, Arcturus in the Bootes is called the star of wheat.
In Japan, Arcturus in the Bootes is called the star of wheat.
In Japan, Arcturus in the Bootes is called the star of wheat.

sen.j: 何れもがその経度に於けるムギの穂が実る時期に表れる星で農業に於ける収穫時期に共通した信仰があった事が伺える。
sen.e: Each of them appears in the season when the crops of wheat are fully grown at the longitude, indicating that there was a common faith in the star for the harvesting season.
Each of them appears in the season when the crops of wheat are fully grown at the longitude, indicating that there was a common faith in the star for the harvest season in agriculture.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。「農業に於ける」の部分を補足、harvesting→ harvestに修正しました。
sen.e: Each of them appears in the season when the crops of wheat are fully grown at the longitude, indicating that there was a common faith in the star for the harvest season in agriculture.

sen.j: 縄文の神話
sen.e: Myth in Jomon Period
Myth in Jomon Period
Myth in Jomon Period

sen.j: 神話学者の吉田敦彦は、縄文時代中期の土偶の大半が地母神的な女性を表現しており、さらに破壊されていることに注目した。
sen.e: A mythologist Atsuhiko YOSHIDA paid his attention to the fact that the majority of earthen figures from the mid Jomon Period depict females like earth mother and have been destroyed.
A mythologist Atsuhiko YOSHIDA paid his attention to the fact that the majority of earthen figures made during the mid Jomon Period depict females like earth mother and have destroyed.
sen.cmt: from mid～→made during mid～に、have been→haveに修正しました。
sen.e: A mythologist Atsuhiko YOSHIDA paid his attention to the fact that the majority of earthen figures made during the mid Jomon Period depict females like earth mother and have destroyed.

sen.j: これは「地母神が殺されてバラバラにされ、そこから人々の役に立つものが誕生した」という神話を、女神の表象である土偶を破壊して分割することによって儀礼的に再現したものではないか、と考えたのである。
sen.e: Yoshida thought that people in Jomon Period reproduced the myth of earth mother who was killed and dismembered but useful things appeared from the parts of her body by destroying and dismembering earthen figures that were symbols of goddess.

Yoshida thought that people in Jomon Period reproduced the myth of 'earth mother who was killed and dismembered but useful things appeared from the parts of her body' by destroying and dismembering earthen figures that were symbols of goddess.
sen.cmt: かぎ括弧を足しました。
sen.e: Yoshida thought that people in Jomon Period reproduced the myth of 'earth mother who was killed and dismembered but useful things appeared from the parts of her body' by destroying and dismembering earthen figures that were symbols of goddess.

sen.j: この説によるとハイヌウェレ型神話は芋（あるいは五穀）栽培とともにすでに縄文中期に日本列島で知られていた、ということになる。
sen.e: If this theory were true, people throughout Japan in the mid Jomon Period had already been familiar with the Hainuwele-type myth and cultivation of potatoes (or five grains).
If this theory were true, people throughout Japan in the mid Jomon Period had already been familiar with the Hainuwele-type myth and cultivation of potatoes (or five grains).
If this theory were true, people throughout Japan in the mid Jomon Period had already been familiar with the Hainuwele-type myth and cultivation of potatoes (or five grains).
